title: IT@Breakfast: Droneport
description:
This 2-hour seminar was hosted by Droneport, a revolutionary organization that specializes in drone technology. This was the first seminar out of the 8 that are required to pass for I-Talent course.
 During this seminar
 the guest speaker showed some cases where drones can be of great help. 
Furthermore, the tech behind drones was explained on a high level.

title: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
description:
This seminar was organised by the Hogeschool PXL & Belfius. A guest speaker came who was an A.I. consultant of Bright Knight, a sister company under the Belfius group. 
He explained why it was important that people start experimenting with A.I. technology and why it won't fade away in the upcoming years.

title: AppFoundry: Introduction to Mobile Development
description: In this seminar, we learnt what technologies are behind the different mobile platforms (IOS / Android). The guest speakers were consultants of AppFoundry, a company that specializes in mobile application development. One speaker had several years of experience in building IOS applications, the other was specialized in Android applications.

title: Workshop Cyber Security
description: This workshop was held by a consultant of Eurofins. In this workshop we teamed in groups of tree to try and hack a virtual server box that was provided by the guest speaker. We needed to 'capture-the-flag' by using a Kali-Linux VM.

title: Build Your Own Server Farm
description: This seminar was held by two network/system engineers of Axxes consultancy. I learned a lot about how to start building my server farm at home and what to look out for. Also, we build a Docker VM and deploy it on the server farm of one of the guest speakers who had set it up for this seminar.

title: Digital@Breakfast: Facebook and me
description: This seminar as held by Tim Verheyden, a journalist of Canvas. He made a documentary where he takes a closer look at the social media company's history and plans for the near future. He also tried to get answers around the modern-day problems of social media like privacy and the impact on democracy. He explained his documentary in a two-hour seminar and shared his experiences that he had while filming the docu.

title: Dialoflow: Build a chatbot
description: In this workshop, I was introduced to Google's Dialogflow platform. I build a chatbot with it. The chatbot is a helpdesk-like chatbot called PXL-Airport. It can answer some questions like 'At what time is the next flight to x?' & 'Where can I park?'. The chatbot calls an API of Brussels Airport to answer these questions. I found it easy to make and the platform show much promise for the future. It is very user-friendly and easy to use. It also has a lot of additional features to let you use it in your own applications. This seminar held by a consultant of Interacto.

title: IoT in Everyday Life
description: The seminar was organized by Infofarm, a Data Science and Big Data consultancy organization. This seminar was nothing more than showing some examples of projects that Inforfarm does that were related to IoT. The seminar ended with a demo.

title: Drinking a river of IoT data with Akka.net
description: This seminar was hosted by Axxes. It explained some basic knowledge about IoT, what it is and what purpose it has. In the second part, we started to build a program that could read mock-data of a sensor. For this, we used a .NET framework called Akka.NET. Akka.NET is a toolkit and runtime for building highly concurrent, distributed, and fault-tolerant event-driven applications on .NET & Mono. Because IoT devices will send a lot of data were not all data is needed every millisecond, it is of great importance that programs behind these IoT-devices are built concurrently.

title: Serverless Applications
description: This seminar was hosted at ACA-IT by the company itself. I was shown what a serverless application are. I never heard of it before. Now I know that these applications are event-driven cloud-based systems where application development rely solely on a combination of third-party service. I teamed up with another developer and build a small node JS application during this seminar as an exercise to have a more firm understanding how serverless applications work.

title: What The Hack! 2019
description: What the hack is one of the biggest and well-organised hackathons of Belgium. It is held every year by Tobania, a big IT-consultancy company. I entered the hackathon with a four-man team. Together. we developed 'MindShare'. An android mobile application that helps psychologists and their patients by keeping a type of daily log of the progression of patients. The application asks some playful questions to the patients and by answering them they reveal their emotional state. The psychologist can then evaluate the answers of his/her patients and give guidance remotely.

title: B-Inspired
description: B-Inspired is an evening filled with short presentations of guest- and intern speakers. These speakers all present a different topic of IT in which they are specialized. It is a great way to share knowledge and a fun way to learn new aspects of the technology sector. The intern speakers are employees of the Bewire group. Bewire is an organization where I did a project throughout the whole first semester of my graduate year. Bewire exits out of a lot of different companies. Each has its focus and purpose in the group. That's why, after all the presentations, there was a networking event for all employees and interns to get together.

title: Hack the Future
description: Hack the future is a hackathon held by the Cronos group and took place on 28/12/2019. The location of this event is an old fortress in the province of Antwerp. This location does let you feel more engaged in the competition. It looks like a villain's hideout. The theme of the hackathon was heisting a bank so it matched with the location. This hackathon is for graduate technology students only, there aren't any professionals participating. The theme of the I took on the Javascript challenge. Everyone was paired with another developer. The challenge was to build a dashboard with a given API. To fully understand how the API worked, each team must solve some riddles that lead to different endpoints of the API.
